title: Lawyer who claimed he could barely walk ‘caught out after getting over-excited at court’
text:
Lawyer Alan Blacker arriving at Minshull Street Crown Court (Picture: Cavendish)

A lawyer who claimed he could barely walk was caught out when he became ‘particularly’ elated during a case, a court has heard.

Dr Alan Blacker is accused of illegally pocketing £60,000 in disability handouts and denies benefit fraud.

The 47-year-old had said he was only able to walk with ‘much intrepidity, pain and fear of falling after only 20 yards,’ it was alleged.

But a jury heard he was filmed by investigators ‘moving with ease’ at a courthouse following a crown court trial victory.

Blacker also allegedly helped construct a miniature railway and undertook first aid training while claiming state handouts between September 1997 and October 2015, his trial heard.

Lawyer Alan Blacker is accused of failing to tell the DWP of his change in health (Picture: Cavendish)

Minshull Crown Court in Manchester heard that Blacker claimed disability allowance, including a high rate mobility component.

Advertisement

Advertisement

That is usually applicable to claimants who have no legs or feet or are 100% blind and/or 80% deaf.

Blacker said his problems began in 1996 and in a claim form two years later, he wrote: ‘My whole life centres around avoiding pain. I cannot carry on through life without it really impacting me and causing me real pain.

‘I am not able to focus on any other thing.’

But prosecutor Chloe Fordham told the jury that Blacker had failed to tell the Department of Work and Pensions (DWP) that his condition had actually improved.

She said: ‘Witnesses describe many circumstances where he was engaged in a number of actions such as first aid training, which requires physical actions and the construction of a model railway.

‘He was seen walking up and down stairs and getting into and out of vehicles without difficulty.

‘He was seen to use a stick but there was nobody helping him standing or walking.

‘He believed he was someone who was entitled to retain his benefits but the prosecution say he was dishonest about the changes in his circumstances in order to continue to claim disability living allowance.’

Alan Blacker in his legal robes (Picture: Cavendish)

Ms Fordham added that Blacker said he had trouble with his balance and needed someone for ‘physical support’ to get to the bathroom.

The court heard the defendant, from Rochdale, Greater Manchester, also said he could walk no more than 20 yards, had trouble standing and needed help cutting up his food, eating and drinking.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Blacker was arrested in 2014 after officials from the DWP filmed him ‘moving with ease’ during a trial at Cardiff Crown Court.

The jury was told Blacker is a solicitor advocate and practiced law through a charity and not for financial gain

Ms Fordham added: ‘He told them he won a Crown Court case on behalf of a client and he became particularly elated.

‘But it must have been clear to Alan Backer that once he was able to move around, he should have informed those facts to the DWP.

‘But he knew that would affect his entitlement.’

Blacker’s benefits were stopped in 2016 following a review.

The trial continues.
